document.title: 2021 Minnesota K12 Academic Standards in Social Studies Final

8148CE9950454A23B2893877AAE09A63.description:
Identify examples of individuals or groups who have had an
impact on world history. Explain how the actions of these
individuals and groups have helped shape the world around
them and the world today.

D850EEC863EF470899B50CF046CC5475.description:
Ways of Knowing and
Methodologies: Use ethnic and
Indigenous studies methods and
sources in order to understand
the roots of contemporary
systems of oppression and apply
lessons from the past that could
eliminate historical and
contemporary injustices.

62DAD2EAA24C498A8CE26A4FA9352631.description:
Identify the processes and impacts of colonization and examine
how discrimination and the oppression of various racial and
ethnic groups have produced resistance movements.

6B422B4317BE47FAABCE950F41048C66.description:
Ways of Knowing and
Methodologies: Use ethnic and
Indigenous studies methods and
sources in order to understand
the roots of contemporary
systems of oppression and apply
lessons from the past that could
eliminate historical and
contemporary injustices.

2A378EA7F0CD409AA1E6AC19FD553442.description:
Explain the role that stereotypes and images based on race,
religion, geography, ethnicity and gender play in the
construction of an individual’s/group’s identity. Identify the
implications associated with these stereotypes and images and
how and why they may have changed over time.

198D95F5A4244D688554E4F7F332110B.description:
Identity: Analyze the ways
power and language construct
the social identities of race,
religion, geography, ethnicity,
and gender. Apply these
understandings to one’s own
social identities and other groups
living in Minnesota, centering
those whose stories and histories
have been marginalized, erased,
or ignored.

F0E8A5228227439C93A3DF0E07D411CA.description:
Investigate government responses to migration and
immigration both locally and nationally.

7967E944EF114EA8BDDCE30907E23B82.description:
Identity: Analyze the ways
power and language construct
the social identities of race,
religion, geography, ethnicity,
and gender. Apply these
understandings to one’s own
social identities and other groups
living in Minnesota, centering
those whose stories and histories
have been marginalized, erased,
or ignored.

D1FA56349F574F2D9821D48799724FA9.description:
Create a timeline demonstrating a sequence of events related
to a contemporary local or global issue.

EB3E29A6DFFC4A779CA390A9963CDC6C.description:
Causation and
Argumentation: Integrate
evidence from multiple historical
sources and interpretations into a
reasoned argument or compelling
narrative about the past.

6C4CC2526BBC4A8293022B50F720A4B6.description:
Compare and contrast two historical sources to investigate a
contemporary issue and its historical roots.

8AB7E03B0165467E85A5BD9AF875D566.description:
Historical Sources and
Evidence: Investigate a variety of
historical sources by: a) analyzing
primary and secondary sources;
b) identifying perspectives and
narratives that are absent from
the available sources; and c)
interpreting the historical
context, intended audience,
purpose, and author’s point of
view of these sources.

845D65BB4BED467EAE05BCF5501E2E45.description:
Pose a question about an issue in the community and/or the
contemporary world and investigate its history.

05AE8393759743B2B8200F4DA388B57C.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

203669E2CD5849BF8C0F44D8D52A3116.description:
Analyze how different perspectives have influenced decisions
about where to locate and name places.

719195C9E973438493EA535BB2C8CFEF.description:
Culture: Investigate how
sense of place is impacted by
different cultural perspectives.

45DE0450B43C40F99FA8355F14937419.description:
Explain how changes in climate and choices humans make
impact environments from local to global scales.

D6C2C287E2104245A2124B84B1638542.description:
Human-Environment
Interaction: Evaluate the
relationship between humans
and the environment, including
climate change.

FCE86932D2CD4292B1871D006EA1C20D.description:
Describe physical and human characteristics needed for
different types of agricultural and energy production regions.

1DEFFB97F9E54F5D95ADC5B49DCEE6D5.description:
Places and Regions: Describe
places and regions, explaining
how they are influenced by
power structures.

D9C3FC4435064A2D9294FA7301953B72.description:
Use maps and concepts of location to identify and describe
political features (states/territories, major cities, capitals) and
recognize the Indigenous land these places were built on.

8AB7A2283AD244F1838C176F7CB039E5.description:
Places and Regions: Describe
places and regions, explaining
how they are influenced by
power structures.

0D5A2CE0FFFE41528AEB11A3BA0BA853.description:
Ask spatial questions and acquire geographic sources from
different perspectives to answer them.

7EAEBF03A7D645F2A5201343D8154DBE.description:
Geospatial Skills and Inquiry:
Apply geographic tools, including
geospatial technologies, and
geographic inquiry to solve
spatial problems.

88CC80A484F34BBAA46680FA79A42E6B.description:
Analyze both fixed and dynamic maps using the TODALSS
criteria when investigating places from local to global scales.

31D6A7CE6DD34C4985F0F67FB979ADB2.description:
Geospatial Skills and Inquiry:
Apply geographic tools, including
geospatial technologies, and
geographic inquiry to solve
spatial problems.

B732CBF891204BAE8FAB5C6D8B3EA8D8.description:
Explain how a nation’s resources influence the goods and
services it can produce and why people in different cultures,
regions or countries may make different decisions about
resource use.

D460EA1661354C6DAFC5EB94B7466EFA.description:
Macroeconomics: Measure
and evaluate the well-being of
nations and communities using a
variety of indicators. Explain the
causes of economic ups and
downs. Evaluate how
government actions affect a
nation’s economy and
individuals’ well-being within an
economy.

72F32D87EE6747BAA368D33412F9DD80.description:
Explain what it means for a resource to be productive and how
productivity can increase.

A5E08B839B104AEBA36D7FDBDCD872F5.description:
Microeconomics: Explain and
evaluate how resources are used
and how goods and services are
distributed within different
economic systems. Analyze how
incentives influence the decisions
of consumers, producers, and
governments. Evaluate the
intended and unintended
consequences of these decisions
from multiple perspectives.

38821F7B27404373B9430E8BC7D2FD94.description:
Explain how incentives can change people’s decisions about
resource use.

1DCEDE8BDF17430198896E2C871894B7.description:
Fundamental Economic
Concepts: Analyze how scarcity
and artificial shortages force
individuals, organizations,
communities, and governments
to make choices and incur
opportunity costs. Analyze how
the decisions of individuals,
organizations, communities, and
governments affect economic
equity and efficiency.

3EE17FD5BC1E4111AFBA110EA0189B07.description:
Explain how the limited supply of natural resources requires
people to make decisions about resource use, and examine a
specific resource use decision made in your community.

374EDD83E0E546E18E252926154144BC.description:
Economic Inquiry: Use
economic models and reasoning
and data analysis to construct an
argument and propose a solution
related to an economic question.
Evaluate the impact of the
proposed solution on various
communities that would be
affected.

8AC08B45E7834FE3AFE5F2483CE23E80.description:
Locate areas inhabited by Indigenous people united by language
and similar ways of life in North America and understand the
impact of permanent tribal homelands on Indigenous people of
Minnesota.

D4448A6E18F44D00B9724B8BC0C1ECA4.description:
Tribal Nations: Evaluate the
unique political status, trust
relationships and governing
structures of sovereign Tribal
Nations and the United States.

0356BAEFAE5D482DAC447494B4F6CBC6.description:
Examine how identity shapes our perspectives about a local
issue and describe ways particular community problems are
addressed.

D4ECF414198F405DADFE6ADB59D413AF.description:
Public Policy: Analyze how
public policy is shaped by
governmental and nongovernmental institutions.
Analyze how people and
communities take action to solve
problems and shape public policy.

65E962127B15411EBB10CCDE0A282088.description:
"List personal group associations and name personal roles and
responsibilities to each of those groups. "

7CBF9A9BE2B04E72A5712A931F00FD81.description:
Governmental Institutions and
Political Processes: Explain and
evaluate processes, rules and
laws of United States
governmental institutions at
local, state and federal levels and
within Tribal Nations.

40EADE997B8F467ABBE485044B939BC0.description:
Describe how democratic values including fairness, equality,
justice, rule of law, freedom and/or individual rights guide and
impact the classroom.

F94B2BF1654348A1A80B9A21B6804482.description:
Democratic Values and
Principles: Explain democratic
values and principles that guide
governments, societies and
communities. Analyze the
tensions within the United States
constitutional government.

9D496BC119BD4E1692FCB2DE5B238D1A.description:
Describe how consensus building is used to identify and
respond to a community problem.

1E7E26A873694152827FAD73AA770921.description:
Civic Skills: Apply civic
reasoning and demonstrate civic
skills for the purpose of informed
and engaged lifelong civic
participation.
